subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Spam
msgSnippet: I am hoping I won t have to go that route, but I will if the amount of spam (spams?) increases to the point that it is hampering legitimate communication.  We
messageBody:
I am hoping I won't have to go that route, but I will if the amount of spam (spams?) increases to the point that it is hampering legitimate communication.  We haven't had a huge number of postings either although I would like to see the level of activity increase.

I would like to have a site where people could practice their Quikscript reading and writing.  I believe practice in reading other's writing is crucial for developing fluency.  Previously, I have noticed that the level of activity on the bulletin boards such as Ikon was very limited.  Not much palaver back and forth ever developed.  Perhaps, we would do better to add short poems and prose pieces to the files section on Reed_Alphabet for newbies to read.  Uploading these sorts of things would also give us an opportunity to critique each other's writing as I doubt many of us are expert Quikscript writers.

I was thinking last night that Shavian has its placement in Unicode now, and it would make sense for use to apply for unicode placement for Quikscript as well.

I was comparing QS to Shavian the other night with the copy of Androcles and the Lion which I recently purchased from Phillip Newton.  I was wondering about the possibility of trying to combine the two alphabets in a manner that both the Shavian devotees and the Reed_Alphabet devotees might be able to agree upon.  It had seemed that this might be possible since the two alphabet share many similarities.  However, as I perused the Shavian alphabet, it once again struck me why I prefer QS.  I know the Shavian devotees decry Reed's abandonment of some of the mirror letters in QS that exist in Shavian because they appreciate the structure of using mirror letters for voiced and unvoiced consonants.  However, this structure means little to most writers since they are not linguists and don't have a clue whether "t" is voiced or unvoiced.  In fact, the question of voiced or unvoiced consonants has nothing to do with learning to make and use the symbol for a given phoneme.

I believe that the changes in the alphabet from Shavian to QS, which essentially simplied the symbols and provided more connection points, thus giving QS its cursive appearance, allow a writer to write more fluidly and quickly.  I believe this is exactly the goal Reed was trying to achieve after he had seen Shavian in use for a sufficient period of time by writers from a number of different countries.

The argument, which I have seen made, that most writing nowadays is on computer is belied by the number of pens and pencils and post-it notes still being sold.  And children still learn to write with pencils, not computers.  I daresay no school system has decided that children can get by with just learning keyboard skills.  A related aspect of Shavian which I find problematical is that some of the vowel symbols are more complicated than they need to be, which makes writin them slower and harder than the equivalent QS symbols, which I find cleaner and simpler.  Also, my 55 year old eyes have a little trouble distinguishing one symbol from another in smaller fonts when I don't have a pair of cheaters handy.  I could go on but don't have the time presently.  

These and similar thoughts made it questionable in my mind that the two alphabets could be successfully reunited.  Shavian devotees will not want to give up their familiar letter shapes, and Reed_Alphabet devotees will not want to give up theirs.  For instance, how do we decide whether the symbols for "th" in Shavian be altered to mean "f" and "v" as they are in QS, or should it be the other way round?  I don't feel it practicable to use Shavian for "print" forms and QS for "handwritten" forms as someone wrote a few months back.  I believe the difference between the symbols of the two alphabets can fairly be called cognitive dissonance.  If one is acclimated that a QS "f" represents "f", it slows reading down a great deal, if you have to make the transition to realize it is a "th" in Shavian or vice-versa.  This problem was exacerbated by Reed's recycling of some Shavian symbols by remapping them onto different phonemes in QS.  Perhaps, I am making too much out of this.  Any thoughts?

Paige Gabhart



Chuck Peck wrote:
Hello Paige,
 
I also run a Yahoo group and I finaly had to only allow postings from members. WHen someone requests to become a member I email them directly and try to insure its not a spammer. My group is small and gets only a few postings a month so its not too hard ot keep up with.
 
Chuck

Paige Gabhart <pgabhart@...> wrote:
The most recent spam has been deleted from messages and the e-mail
address for one of them has been deleted.  The other one I cannot
find in the list of members so that may be solved as well.  We will
see.

Paige Gabhart
